title: Ticwatch S Review: Android Wear On The Cheap
description: Last year, while mourning the loss of my favorite smartwatch maker to a Fitbit acquisition, I was given hope by a wearable called the Ticwatch 2. It featured an innovative operating system and a very clever touch-sensitive strip for controlling it. Well recently, almost 20,000 people pledged about 3.2 million dollars on Kickstarter to bring its sequel to life. The Ticwatch S ditches its predecessor's proprietary OS for Android Wear, but it also eliminates its single most interesting feature in favor of affordability. Join MrMobile for the Ticwatch S Review!   [SPONSOR]  This video was made possible by Thrifter, a new way to save money on everything from gadgets to home goods by shopping based on value, not hype. To get all the leaked ads and the best deals, check out Thrifter here:    [SUBSCRIBE]     [PRODUCTS IN THIS VIDEO]  Ticwatch S:    [ABOUT MRMOBILE'S AXON M REVIEW]  MrMobile's Ticwatch S Review was produced following ten days with a Ticwatch S review device provided by Mobvoi. The watch was paired with an Axon M review unit and received no software updates during the test period. transcript: - [Speaker] About a year ago, while I was mourning the loss of two of my favorite smartwatch makers to a Fitbit acquisition, I was given hope for the future by a wearable called the Ticwatch 2. It featured an innovative operating system and a very clever, touch-sensitive strip for controlling it. Well, recently, almost twenty-thousand people pledged about three-point-two million dollars on Kickstarter, to bring it's sequel to life. I'm Mr Mobile, and this is the Ticwatch S. This is actually one of two new Ticwatches, the more fitness oriented S model. The less sporty E version, features a translucent casing design, and it moves the GPS antennas from the band, into the watch body, so the user can swap the straps. I kinda wish I'd gotten to take a look at the E, because I like it's look better, to me the S seems like a pretty generic sports watch. With a plastic and polyurethane build that fails to stand out, apart from these superfluous bezel marks. As with the last tech watch, the button is on the left side, but unlike last year's model, it's hard as a rock, with almost no physical feedback. Also, last year's tickle strip, that touch sensitive pad, is gone. So, you're stuck with the screen alone, for controlling the software. This is the most confusing part of the whole product to me. I understand why Mobvoi, the maker of the Ticwatch, would ditch it's own software platform for Android Wear, as it's done here. I mean, the ecosystem of apps and watch faces is huge, so that makes sense. But, why eliminate a useful feature that helps the watch stand out in an increasingly crowded landscape? I mean, Samsung has the active bezel on it's gear line. Apple, LG, and Movado use a rotating side button for scrolling, and Ticwatch had the touch strip, until now. And, this is more than just a superficial, or geeky thing, a digital dial makes Android wear much more fluid to use. And a touch strip would do the same. But, maybe I'm expecting too much. All the watches I just mentioned, are substantially more expensive than the Ticwatch S or E. Meanwhile, there's not a hint of penny pinching apparent on the display, who's OLED panel is bright, sharp, and quite beautiful. I especially like the included watch faces, with colors that closely match the bezel accents. Nice attention to detail, there. The watch is also IP67 rated for dust and water resistance, and it offers a microphone, speaker, WIFI, in short, most of the fundamentals. The only major omissions are cellular connectivity, and NFC. So, if you're looking for a stand-alone phone watch, or something you can use with Android Pay, look elsewhere. I've worn the Ticwatch S for about a week, and it's been a positive experience. The battery size is typical, and so is the endurance it enables. I get about a day-and-a-half between charges, as long as I don't use that power-hungry GPS. There were apparently some complaints about location accuracy, on the last Ticwatch, they've been corrected here. And, there's also a fitness sweep, that hits the basics, if you don't want to use Google Fit for whatever reason. For charging, I initially missed having an included pedestal for bedside table use, but then I remembered how cheap, and rubbery, and just awful it was on the Ticwatch 2. So, I came around to liking the low-profile included cable. You definitely need to take this magnetic charger with you on a trip, but it takes up so little space, you probably won't mind much. The Ticwatch S retails for 199, while the E model comes in cheaper, at 159. And it's that appeal to the frugal, that makes this rather typical smartwatch, notable. Those prices are much lower than most of the competition I've covered this year; like the LG Watch Sport, or the Casio Pro Trek F20. Now, if you head over to Amazon and sort the Android Wear catalog by price, there are a few solid options that are as good, or better, right in the same neighborhood. But, the majority of them are older, or even discontinued models. So, if what you want is a new product, and the design speaks to you, the Ticwatch S and E are definitely worth a look. I just wish they carried over more of the innovative spirit of their forerunner. Speaking of saving dough, this video is brought to you by Thrifter, a new way to save money on everything from gadgets, to home goods. By shopping based on value, not hype. Click the link down on the description for all the best deals, dug up by the talented team at Thrifter, daily, at thrifter.com. Til next time folks, thanks for watching. Please subscribe, and stay mobile, my friends.
